The grizzled forest workers likened this tiny owl's call-a high, sharp series of hoots often repeating for hours-to the familiar sound of a whetstone honing a saw tooth by tooth. Though best recognized for making noise, the pint-size predator is great at hearing it, too: As with many owl species, the saw-whet's ears are asymmetrical in structure and placement, allowing it to triangulate upon prey with fierce precision using sound alone.","copyright":"c Megan Lorenz / Adobe Stock","likeGlyph":"?","dislikeGlyph":"?","ctaText":"Learn {"f":"raf","v":"1.0","rdr":[{"c":"CDMLite","u":"DesktopSpotlightSurface"}],"ad":{"landscapeImage":{"asset":"https://res.public.onecdn.static.microsoft/creativeservice/def1c685-892e-3695-fa39-726ebf606dfd_desktop-b010_ds_wallsnorthyorkshire_gettyimages-1482758840_3840x2160.jpg"},"portraitImage":{"asset":"https://res.public.onecdn.static.microsoft/creativeservice/410659e0-dc90-4997-6246-a2a73369b486_desktop-b010_ds_wallsnorthyorkshire_gettyimages-1482758840_1080x1920.jpg"},"iconLabel":"Learn about this picture","iconHoverText":"Dry stone walls in the Yorkshire Dales, England\r\nc Alexander W Helin / Moment / Getty Images\r\nRight-click to learn more","title":"Hill, dale, and dry stone","description":"Layers of limestone in this pastural portion of Northern England not only define the rolling landscape, they provide prime construction material for the walls corralling the area's wooliest denizens. Generations of skilled stonemasons have carefully arranged these stacks of limestone slabs that vary widely in size and shape, using techniques that maximize surface contact between the stones. Thanks to the everyday science of friction, a well-built dry stone wall can be as sturdy as solid concrete. The walls here in the Yorkshire Dales collectively stretch 5,000 miles, many of them several centuries old.","copyright":"c Alexander W Helin / Moment / Getty Images","likeGlyph":"?","dislikeGlyph":"?","ctaText":"Learn {"f":"raf","v":"1.0","rdr":[{"c":"CDMLite","u":"DesktopSpotlightSurface"}],"ad":{"landscapeImage":{"asset":"https://res.public.onecdn.static.microsoft/creativeservice/28f48183-15a7-bc97-b6a4-4ce6302b27c3_desktop-b018_ds_slothcecropiatree_gettyimages-2159861771_3840x2160.jpg"},"portraitImage":{"asset":"https://res.public.onecdn.static.microsoft/creativeservice/06f4f6eb-9aa3-1581-a512-51aab79d9195_desktop-b018_ds_slothcecropiatree_gettyimages-2159861771_1080x1920.jpg"},"iconLabel":"Learn about this picture","iconHoverText":"Three-toed sloth\r\nc Juan Carlos Vindas / Moment / Getty Images\r\nRight-click to learn more","title":"Let's hang","description":"If you're moving slow today, that's just fine: You're outpacing our rainforest-dwelling photo subject, which spends 90% of its time scarcely moving a muscle. Sloths (this one's a three-toed sloth-count 'em) move very little to conserve the scant energy gained from their leaves-only diet. They live most of their lives hanging from their hooked claws in trees like this cecropia, whose leaves are a favorite sloth food. Sloths even sleep in a dangling position, and they often snooze away 20 hours of the day. Jealous?","copyright":"c Juan Carlos Vindas / Moment / Getty Images","likeGlyph":"?","dislikeGlyph":"?","ctaText":"Learn {"f":"raf","v":"1.0","rdr":[{"c":"CDMLite","u":"DesktopSpotlightSurface"}],"ad":{"landscapeImage":{"asset":"https://res.public.onecdn.static.microsoft/creativeservice/d4385acb-5bbb-fd5b-8b68-d5b3aaabd8ed_desktop-b018_ds_snowmonkeyparkspring_gettyimages-147182214_3840x2160.jpg"},"portraitImage":{"asset":"https://res.public.onecdn.static.microsoft/creativeservice/7269d34b-4fd2-24a0-094c-5625fb4d8c8a_desktop-b018_ds_snowmonkeyparkspring_gettyimages-147182214_1080x1920.jpg"},"iconLabel":"Learn about this picture","iconHoverText":"Jigokudani Monkey Park, Japan\r\nc Chin Ping, Goh / Moment / Getty Images\r\nRight-click to learn more","title":"Simian snuggles","description":"This snuggling trio of young Japanese macaques-aka snow monkeys-may have a touch of frost in their fur, but this spot has just the cure for winter chills. When the weather outside is frightful, snow monkeys of all ages descend from the forest and soak in the hot springs, known as onsen, found here at Jigokudani Monkey Park. It's said that in the 1960s, someone tossed an apple to a monkey who then chased it into an onsen. Rather than bound back out, the monkey stayed put for a steamy soak, and since its fellows followed suit, generations of these simians have been hooked on spa days.","copyright":"c Chin Ping, Goh / Moment / Getty Images","likeGlyph":"?","dislikeGlyph":"?","ctaText":"Learn
